item.title: The Three Pillars: Why I Engineer, Create, and Train
item.description:
Most people talk about “work-life balance” like it’s a scale you’re supposed to keep level. I think that’s backwards.

Balance implies trade-offs. It suggests that gaining in one area means losing in another. But what if the areas aren’t competing—they’re compounding?

That’s the philosophy behind my Three Pillars: Engineer. Artist. Athlete.

The Engineer: Building Systems

Engineering isn’t just my profession—it’s how I think.

I see the world as systems: inputs, processes, outputs, feedback loops. Whether I’m writing Rust code for embedded systems or planning my week, I’m optimizing for efficiency and robustness.

item.title: My Journey into Embedded Systems: From Arduino to Production IoT
item.description:
The path to embedded systems engineering isn’t always linear. Mine started with a simple Arduino Uno and an LED blink sketch, but it evolved into architecting fail-safe bootloaders for production IoT devices.

The Beginning: Curiosity and LEDs

Like many engineers, my first “embedded system” was making an LED blink. Simple, right? But that tiny victory sparked something deeper—a fascination with the intersection of hardware and software, where every CPU cycle matters and memory is measured in kilobytes, not gigabytes.

item.title: Producing Music with a Coder's Mindset
item.description:
There’s a strange symmetry between writing code and producing music. Both are creative processes constrained by logic. Both require pattern recognition, iteration, and debugging. And both can achieve flow state when everything clicks.

The Algorithm of Sound

When I first opened Logic Pro, I approached it like a new programming language. What are the primitives? What are the constraints? How do I compose complexity from simple elements?

A beat is essentially a loop—a recurring pattern with variations. Sound like anything familiar to programmers?

item.title: Data-Driven Hypertrophy: Analyzing 3 Years of Training Logs
item.description:
The body is hardware. Training is programming. Nutrition is fuel. And data is the debugger that tells you what’s actually working.

After three years of logging every workout, every set, every rep, I finally had enough data to answer the question: What actually drives hypertrophy?

The Dataset

3 years. 1,095 days. ~800 logged workouts. Tracking:

  • Exercise name
  • Sets, reps, weight
  • Rest periods
  • Subjective difficulty (RPE)
  • Body weight and measurements
  • Sleep and recovery metrics

All stored in structured CSV files because, well, I’m an engineer.

item.title: Building Autonomous Systems: Lessons from ROS and SLAM
item.description:
Making a robot navigate autonomously is harder than it looks. Way harder.

On paper, SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) sounds straightforward: the robot builds a map of its environment while tracking its own position within that map. In practice, it’s a beautiful nightmare of sensor fusion, probabilistic algorithms, and edge cases.

The Problem Space

Imagine you’re blindfolded in an unknown room. You can:

  • Sense walls when you touch them (LIDAR)
  • Measure your steps (odometry)
  • Occasionally glimpse landmarks (visual features)

Now navigate the room, build a mental map, and know where you are at all times. That’s SLAM.
